qudipy.design package

Submodules

qudipy.design.designer module

Designer class definition. Its child classes include: DesignerEffective, DesingerCSP, DesingerGRAPE, ColoredNoise, etc. Each of them contains data and methods to design control pulses.

@author: Bohdan Khromets

class qudipy.design.designer.Designer(num_qubits: int, g_idle: float, B_zeeman: float <in tesla> | None = None, f_rf: float <in Hz> | None = None, length: float <in seconds> = 'optimize', bounds: dict = {}, bandwidth: float <in Hz> = inf, max_esr_amp: float <in tesla> = inf, max_esr_energy: float <in joules> = inf)

Bases: object

qudipy.design.effective module

Module for designing effective spin (and maybe Hubbard in the future) pulses for basic quantum gates.

@author: Bohdan Khromets

class qudipy.design.effective.DesignerEffective(num_qubits: int, g_idle: float, B_zeeman: float <in tesla> | None = None, f_rf: float <in Hz> | None = None, shape: str or function on 𝜏∈[0, 1] = 'gaussian', length: float <in seconds> = 'optimize', bounds: dict = {}, bandwidth: float <in Hz> = inf, max_esr_amp: float <in tesla> = inf, max_esr_energy: float <in joules> = inf, **params: dict)

Bases: Designer

static build_shape(name: str, t_start: float = 0, t_end: float = 1, amp: float = 'auto', offset: float = 0, sigma: float = 0.1, **params: dict)
Static method that creates a shape function based on the

desired parameters. See qudipy.design.shapes module for more details.

Required Parameters

namestr

Name of the shape

t_startfloat, optional

Value for which S(t < t_start) = offset

t_endfloat, optional

Value for which S(t > t_end) = offset

ampfloat or str, optional

Amplitude (max value) of shape, or ‘auto’/’automatic’ keyword to determine it automatically from normalization condition ⟨S⟩=1 By default, ‘auto’.

offsetfloat, optional

Shape offset at the beginning and end of pulse, by default 0

sigmafloat, optional

(for a Gaussian shape only) relative half-width, by default 0.1

paramsfloat, optional

Other shape parameters

returns:

Shape function (t

rtype:

np.array) -> np.array

compose(num_steps: int, **design_params) → ControlPulse

Method for composing an effective pulse

Required Parameters

num_stepsint

Number of discrete time steps for a pulse

design_paramsdict, optional

Parameters to add/update in the Designer object. In case of overlap, these parameters have priority over the ones stored as Designer object’s attributes, and the attributes are left intact.

returns:

eff_pulse – Control pulse object with all pulse parameters

rtype:

ControlPulse object

qudipy.design.effective.chpase(N: int, qubit_pairs: pair of ints, or iterable[pairs of ints], angle: float = 3.141592653589793, **designer_params: dict) → DesignerEffective

Cphase(angle) gate

Required parameters

Nint

Total number of qubits in the system

qubit_pairspair of ints, or iterable of pairs of ints

Positions of qubits on which the gate is applied (counting starts from 1).

Optional parameters

anglefloat, optional

Controlled phase. Default is π (Control-Z gate)

designer_paramsdict, optional

Other parameters that may be needed for the creation of a DesignerEffective object, including idling g-factor value, Zeeman field and central ESR frequency. See class definition for more details.

returns:

cphase_designer – DesignerEffective object with a string of coefficients A, ß, C that corresponds to a CPHASE of specified qubit pairs in an N-qubit system

rtype:

DesignerEffective

qudipy.design.effective.hadamard(N: int, qubits: int, or list/tuple/str of ints, **designer_params: dict) → DesignerEffective

Special case of rotation around vector (1,0,1) by π

qudipy.design.effective.rot(N: int, qubits: int, or list/tuple/str of ints, axis: 3-element iterable of floats, or 'X', 'Y', 'Z', angle: float, **designer_params: dict) → DesignerEffective
Parameters:

  • N (int) – Total number of qubits in the system

  • qubits (int or iterable of ints) – Positions of qubits on which the gate is applied (counting starts from 1)

  • axis (iterable of floats or str) – iterable of floats of length 3, or string ‘X’,’Y’,’Z’ specifying the axis of rotation.

  • angle (float) – Angle of rotation [in radians! ]

  • designer_params (dict) – Other parameters needed for the creation of a DesignerEffective object, including idling g-factor value, Zeeman field and central ESR frequency. See class definition for more details.

Returns:

rot_designer – DesignerEffective object with a string of coefficients A, ß, C that corresponds to a rotation of specified qubits in an N-qubit system

Return type:

DesignerEffective

qudipy.design.effective.swapk(N: int, qubit_pairs: pair of ints, or iterable[pairs of ints], k: float = 1, **designer_params: dict) → DesignerEffective

SWAP^k gate

Parameters:

  • N (int) – Total number of qubits in the system

  • qubit_pairs (pair of ints, or iterable of pairs of ints) – Positions of qubits on which the gate is applied (counting starts from 1).

  • k (float) – Exponent of Swap gate. Default is 1 (SWAP gate)

  • designer_params (dict) – Other parameters needed for the creation of a DesignerEffective object, including idling g-factor value, Zeeman field and central ESR frequency. See class definition for more details.

Returns:

swap_designer – DesignerEffective object with a string of coefficients A, ß, C that corresponds to a SWAP^k of specified qubit pairs in an N-qubit system

Return type:

DesignerEffective

qudipy.design.shapes module

Module with a library of functions that define pulse shapes. Each of them returns a shape function that gives the pulse value(s) when applied on the desired value(s) of time.

By default, all shapes are defined for normalized time 𝜏∈[0,1], and normalized by their average values: ⟨S⟩=1

qudipy.design.shapes.gaussian(t_start: float = 0, t_end: float = 1, sigma: float = 0.1, amp: float = 'auto', offset: float = 0)

Creates a Gaussian pulse of relative width sigma that lasts from t_start until t_end. The pulse is shifted and scaled vertically so that the pulse values at the beginning and at the end are equal to the specified offset value. If amplitude is not specified explicitly but set to ‘auto’/’automatic’, the pulse is normalized so that its average value is equal to 1.

Convenient for defining pulses in terms of normalized time tau = (t-t_start) / (t_end - t_start), as 0<=tau<=1, which corresponds to the default values.

Optional Parameters

t_start: float

Time point at which the pulse begins. Default is 0.

t_end: float

Time point at which the pulse ends. Default is 1.

sigma: float

Half-width of the pulse relative to its length. Default is 0.1.

amp: float or str

Amplitude of the pulse. If a keyword ‘auto’/’automatic’ is specified, chosen automatically to normalize

offset: float

Default value of a control variable before and after the pulse. Default is 0.

returns:

gauss_pulse – Function that defines a shifted Gaussian pulse when applied to the desired time value / array of values.

#TODO handle the custom amplitudes and offsets correctly

rtype:

function

qudipy.design.shapes.shifted_gauss(t_start=0, t_end=1, amp=1, offset=0, sigma=0.1)

Creates a Gaussian pulse of amplitude amp and relative width sigma that lasts from t_start until t_end. The pulse is shifted and scaled vertically so that the pulse values at the beginning and at the end are equal to offset.

Convenient for defining pulses in terms of normalized time tau = (t-t_start) / (t_end - t_start), as 0<=tau<=1, which corresponds to the default values.

Optional Parameters

t_start: float

Time point at which the pulse begins. Default is 0.

t_send: float

Time point at which the pulse ends. Default is 1.

amp: float

Amplitude of the pulse. Default is 1.

offset: float

The shift of the Gaussian function vertically; corresponds to the value of the pulse at t_start and t_end. Assumed to be constant before and after the pulse. Default is 0.

sigma: float

Half-width of the pulse (in units of time). Default is 0.1.

returns:

shifted_gauss_pulse – Function that defines a shifted Gaussian pulse when applied to the desired time value(s)

rtype:

function

qudipy.design.shapes.square(t_start: float = 0, t_end: float = 1, amp: float = 1, offset: float = 0)

Creates a square pulse of amplitude amp and that continues from t_start until t_end, and fixed at the specified offset value prior and afterwards. Convenient for defining pulses in terms of normalized time tau = (t-t_start) / (t_end - t_start), as 0<=tau<=1, which corresponds to the default values.

Optional Parameters

t_start: float

Time point at which the pulse begins. Default is 0.

t_end: float

Time point at which the pulse ends. Default is 1.

amp: float

Amplitude of the pulse. Default is 1.

offset: float

Default value of a control variable before and after the pulse. Default is 0.

returns:

square_pulse – Function that defines a square pulse when applied to the desired time value / array of values.

rtype:

function

qudipy.design.shapes.triangle(t_start: float = 0, t_end: float = 1, amp: float = 2, offset: float = 0)

Creates a symmetric triangular pulse of amplitude amp and that continues from t_start until t_end. The pulse starts and ends at a constant value of offset. If amplitude is not specified explicitly but set to ‘auto’/’automatic’, the pulse is normalized so that its average value is equal to 1.

Convenient for defining pulses in terms of normalized time tau = (t-t_start) / (t_end - t_start), as 0<=tau<=1, which corresponds to the default values.

Optional Parameters

t_start: float

Time point at which the pulse begins. Default is 0.

t_end: float

Time point at which the pulse ends. Default is 1.

amp: float

Amplitude of the pulse. Default is 1.

offset: float

Default value of a control variable before and after the pulse. Default is 0.

returns:

square_pulse – Function that defines a triangular pulse when applied to the desired time value / array of values.

rtype:

function

qudipy.design.voltage_pulses module

Module that contains methods that design “simple” one- and two-qubit gates. Will return control pulse objects eventually, but now it is used only to find pulse duration or amplitude

@author: Madi Schuetze

qudipy.design.voltage_pulses.balance_zeeman(delta_g_interp, v_offset, f_rf, material)

Find the value of Zeeman field that ensures no qubit rotations at idling.

delta_g_interp: function

(ideally, but only one interpolating function for now) Iterable of interpolating functions delta g_i(

ec{V}) for

all qubits, including inactive ones

v_offset: Float

Voltage offset when no pulse is applied.

f_rf: float

ESR frequency.

s

  • delta_g_interp to take Anyof(Float Int) and return Anyof(Float Int)

  • v_offset to take Anyof(Float Int) and return Anyof(Float Int)

B_0: float

The value of Zeeman field that ensures no rotation occurs on any of the idling qubits

qudipy.design.voltage_pulses.create_ctlp_file(CntrlPulse, read=False, get_dir=False)

@author: Madi

Creates a .ctrlp file containing the information about a rotation gate from a ControlPulse object

Parameters:

  • CntrlPulse (ControlPulse) – Control Pulse Object

  • read (Bool) – If read = True, the function will print out the .ctrlp file, if read = False (Default) the funciton will print nothing

  • get_dir (Bool) – If get_dir = True, the function will return the directory as a string, if get_dir = False (Default), the function will return nothing

Returns:

  • Str *conditional* – Returns the directory of the file as a str if get_dir = True, otherwise, the function returns None

  • None

  • Effects

  • ————-

  • Creates a .ctrlp file containing all information to re-create the same ControlPulse

  • object

  • Prints to screen *conditional - prints the Control Pulse file to the screen if*

  • read = True, otherwise, nothing is printed to the screen

qudipy.design.voltage_pulses.create_quantum_circuit(list_ctrlp, circuit_name, write_qcirc=False, print_dir=False)

@author: Madi

Takes directory to a .qcirc file, creates the necessary ControlPulses for rotations around an axis, creates a dictionary of these specified ControlPulse objects and returns a QuantumCircuit Object

Parameters:

  • list_ctrlp (Listof(Str(.ctrlp))) – A list that contains .ctrlp files where these files are specified by strings

  • circuit_name (str) – The name that the user wishes to call the circuit

  • write_qcirc (Bool) – If write_qcirc = True the function will write a qcirc file of the quantum circuit with the name “circuit_name”.qcirc, else the function does nothing

  • print_dir (Bool) – If write_qcirc = True and print_dir = True the function will print the directory of the newly made .qcirc file, else the function does nothing

  • Requires –

  • ---------- –

  • qubits (* All ControlPulse objects act on the same number of) –

  • directory (* All .ctrlp files in list_ctrlp will path to the correct) – -> user must ensure that all directory satisfactions are met

Return type:

QuantumCircuit object

Effects

Writes File conditional

writes a .qcirc file with the name “circuit_name”.qcirc is write_qcirc = True

Prints to Screen

prints the directory of the newly made .qcirc file if print_dir = True and write_qcirc = True

qudipy.design.voltage_pulses.kswap(active_qubit_pairs, N, k, dot_interps, pulse_shape, v_offset, f_rf=None, num_val=300)

Generate a k-swap exchange pulses for the desired qubit pairs and leave the others unaffected.

Parameters:

  • qubits (list of tuples?) –

  • N (number of qubits) – number of qubits

  • dot_interps – dictionary of interpolation objects for all effective parameters

  • pulse_shape – shape function chosen

  • v_offset – starting voltage configuration for the gates

  • Parameters (Optional) –

  • ----------------- –

Return type:

control pulse object with effective parameter pulses

qudipy.design.voltage_pulses.rot(N, qubits, rot_axis, angle, dot_interps, pulse_shape, v_offset, f_rf=None, num_val=100)

Generate a rotation pulses for the desired qubits and leave the others idling.

  • N (number of qubits) – number of qubits

  • dot_interps – dictionary of interpolation objects for all effective parameters

  • pulse_shape – shape function chosen
